column4: Windows doesn't work, it is fragmented so I can't partition the drive, and I don't have the CD. It won't boot in any safe mode or anything.
Yes, hope13.
Or at least put something I can use (ubuntu) on the drive, hope13.
No I don't, hope13.
How do I mount the Windows partition, Goldfisch?
No, hope13. Nothing works like that. Not rebooting from last good boot or anything. Safe mode with command line doesn't even boot.
I don't know, Goldfisch. It is a IBM ThinkPad T22.
You can't boot DOS with XP, FeliLixTKhat. XP isn't like Windows 98, it doesn't sit on top of DOS.
Typing that in the command line doesn't tell me anything I can make sense of, Goldfisch. What exactly tells me whether it is ATA or SATA?
This is not my computer, Goldfisch. The person would be willing to use Ubuntu, but he wants to recover some important files at least.

SATA drives have a smaller connecting cable, compare to ATA, which uses the wide, thin ribbon cable inside the case. SATA mean Serial ATA drive. See => http://images.google.com/imgres?imgurl=http://www.usb-ware.com/images/7-pin-sata-cable.gif&imgrefurl=http://www.usb-ware.com/sata-cables.htm&h=185&w=200&sz=10&tbnid=rUJ5nwDX2TAOOM:&tbnh=96&tbnw=104&prev=/images%3Fq%3Dsata%2Bcable&start=1&sa=X&oi=images&ct=image&cd=1

My Dad spotted a 2G flash stick at Best Buy last week for $40. It may be worth it to go get one. That should give you some flexibility. I have flash thumb drives many times in the past to work on systems.
is there anyway I can get my wireless working to send the files somewhere else?
Not sure. Depends on the card model and all that good stuff. Whenever I shop for wireless cards, I always do a lot of homework to make sure there is documented compatability.
I have no idea what this one is. It doesn't have a name on it.
Well, either "lspci -v" or "lsusb -v" may turn up some information. Can't remember if cardbus/pcmcia reports on either of those commands.
Well, either lspci or cardctl is your ticket. Try those out and see if you get some info on your network card.
I am not sure what I am looking at.
Paste it into http://paste.ubuntu-nl.org and then post a link on this channel.
I can't copy and paste...unless I manually typed out everything. Is there something specific I should look for?

I don't have a laptop in front of me to run these commands, so I'm not sure what you are seeing. You want to find some indication of a network-based card like "802.11" and then some type of vendor/model number in close proximity. Are you in console mode, being the reason you can't cut-and-paste?
I didn't mean the WIndows XP CD. I meant the CD of drivers that came with your wireless card.
I have one PC that uses a wireless card, and I haven't bought a windows disk for two years.
I think I just got an idea. I could possibly fix the NTFS partition with that NTFSFuse program.
